definition: A web API used to fetch data from a server, without the need for a full page refresh.
An object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.
A syntax for writing asynchronous code that looks like synchronous code.
An object representing the response to a fetch request.
A lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate.
An API that provides client functionality for transferring data between a client and a server.
A software architectural style that defines a set of constraints to be used for creating web services.
A set of protocols, routines, and tools for building software and applications.
A URL that is the entry point for a web service.
A code that indicates the status of a HTTP response.
Information that is transmitted along with the HTTP request or response.
A mechanism that allows many resources (e.g., fonts, JavaScript, etc.) on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the resource originated.
The process of verifying the identity of a user or process.
The process of determining whether a user or process has the necessary permissions to access a resource.
A part of a URL that contains data to be passed to web applications.
The data that is sent to a server in a HTTP request.
The HTTP method used to make a request to a server.
A small piece of data stored on the client-side that is sent to the server with every request.
A period of time during which a client interacts with a server.
A mechanism for storing data in memory or on disk so that it can be retrieved more quickly.
